title: Rugby World Cup chiefs savaged by Italy star Sergio Parisse over typhoon tactics
text:

Rugby World Cup bosses were last night accused of disrespect after whipping up a storm with their typhoon tactics, writes Alex Spink in Miyazaki.

A black day for the tournament saw the first ever cancellations with England’s ‘le crunch’ clash with France and New Zealand’s final pool game against Italy biting the dust.

Scotland’s clash on Sunday against host nation Japan could yet go as well as super typhoon Hagibis closes in on Tokyo and its surrounding area.

World Cup boss Alan Gilpin said it was a “difficult” but “right” decision due to safety concerns for supporters bound for Yokohama and Toyota.

(Image: AFP via Getty Images)

But Italy captain Sergio Parisse was scathing - claiming that had they been one of the top-ranked countries the match would have been played.

“If New Zealand needed four or five points against us it would not have been cancelled,” raged Parisse, the second most-capped player in rugby history.

The All Blacks are already through to the quarter-finals, as are England and France. Italy alone needed to play to stand any chance of staying alive.

(Image: PA)

“Sure, everyone might think that Italy versus New Zealand being cancelled counts for nothing because we’d have lost anyway,” Parisse added. “But we deserved to be respected as a team.

“It is ridiculous that there is no Plan B, because it isn’t news that typhoons hit Japan. When you organise a World Cup you should have one in place.”

Organisers can expect an even bigger backlash if Scotland, ranked nine in the world, are eliminated in circumstances as controversial as they are unprecedented.

Like Italy, the Scots need to play or they are out as the standard award of two points for a ‘draw’ would put Japan through instead.

Not surprisingly they were quick onto the front foot yesterday, saying they “fully expected” contingency plans to be put in place to enable them to settle their fate “on the pitch”.

(Image: AFP/Getty Images)

They added that they would be “flexible to accommodate this” - by which they mean prepared to either play the following day or behind closed doors, even at a different venue.

The problem is World Rugby’s insistence that all matches be treated fairly. “Italy are in the same position Scotland are in,” Gilpin said. “We won’t treat that match any different."

A final decision, he added, would be made on Sunday morning and the match would be neither rescheduled nor relocated.

(Image: Getty Images)

The last typhoon to hit Tokyo claimed three lives and the following day there was transport gridlock and logistical chaos. This one is two and a half times bigger.

Japan Airlines is cancelling more than 90% of its domestic flights in and out of Tokyo tomorrow. Scotland’s fate is in the lap of the gods.

It is extraordinary and, frankly, farcical that no flexibility was written into the competition schedule to cope with such an eventuality.

(Image: Getty Images)

World Rugby insist all participating teams agreed to these regulations at the start so there is no legal comeback.

But do not expect that to impress the tens of thousands of supporters in Tokyo for what should have been the rugby weekend of a lifetime.
